Award.AwardTitle: Band Offsets and Interface State Densities in Crystalline and Amorphous Oxide Systems for Photonics, Sensors and Electronics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetic Devices Program (EPMD) in the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems (ECCS) and the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).

Technical Description: The research objective of this project aims to develop a better understanding of the fundamental materials properties of the band offsets and interfaces between dielectrics and semiconductors. It covers investigation of the band offsets for different dielectrics (SiNX, Sc2O3 and (CeTb)MgAl11O19) on crystalline ZnO, CdZnO, ZnMgO and also for the latter two on a-IGZO and measurement of interface state densities and thermal stability of all these dielectrics on a-IGZO. Optical and electrical techniques are used to characterize the band offsets, bandgaps and interface state densities.

Non-technical Description: Crystalline and amorphous electronic oxides are gaining interest for gas and chemical sensing, ultra violet light-emitting diodes for solid state lighting, flat-panel, flexible and touch-screen displays and solar cells. The importance of transparent conducting oxides in these products has led to a surge of research in recent years to discover new materials, lower the costs of manufacture and improve properties. Oxide-based thin film transistors have great potential for realizing a roll-to-roll display. If this can be realized, it may also create new applications in heads-up displays, windshields, electronic books or light weight computers and eventually change the entire display industry. This project is designed to develop a new class of solid-state materials that can be made at low temperatures, allowing their use on cheap substrates like paper and plastic. In addition, cross-disciplinary education activities introduce the public to these exotic and enabling materials. The PI engages in undergraduate and graduate mentoring, K-12 outreach, conference symposia organization, and writing a textbook.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF project was aimed at measuring the conduction and valence band offsets of common dielectric materials on IGZO, a promising new transparent conducting oxide that can be used to make thin film transistors on a wide variety of surfaces. The fact that the IGZO can be deposited at room temperature means that it is compatible with many different types of surfaces,including paper,plastics and different types of fabric.To design these types of transistors, information is needed on a parameter called the band offsets, which is the difference in energy between the bandgap of IGZO and the bandgap of a dielectric material used to produce a gate or switching contact on the transistor. During the course of our NSF project, we have measured this fundamental parameter for roughly 10 different dielectrics on IGZO and 4 on ZnO, a related material that is also promising for new stypes of sensors, light emitters and transparent transistors.The most useful dielectrics and found to be Al2O3 and SiO2. We also measured the effect of how these dielectrics are deposited on the resulting band offsets, including different depsoition methods and sequences and how exposure to air affects the band offsets.the valence band offsets of many different dielectric/IGZO structures, including Y2O3/IGZO, HfO2/IGZO, MgO/IGZO, Al2O3/IGZO, and SiO2/IGZO heterojunctions were determined to be in the range of 0.44-1.43 eV from XPS measurements. Given the bandgap differences between each dielectric material and IGZO, conduction band offsets of 2.39-4.74 eV are more than sufficient to provide a strong carrier confinement in the IGZO channel. A key aspect to achieving good performance of these TFTs is the choice of gate dielectrics. The quality of dielectric/oxide interface plays an important role in TFT characteristics. A poor interface between the channel and gate-dielectric leads to large interface trap density and reduced carrier transport properties, which causes a degradation of device parameters such as leakage current, saturation mobility, and subthreshold gate-voltage swing. The work reported here is the beginning of a systematic study to establish the fundamental parameters of different dielectric/IGZO heterostructures.
